Chinua Achebe

Adrienne Adams

See FOLK: Walter

A.N. Afanasief

Gardaz, Elisabeth. "Trois Traductions du conte Russe d'Afanassiev: Kolobok." La Revue des Livres pour Enfants 145 (Spring 1992): 76-85. Discusses three French translations of the popular Russian folktale. G.A.

Allan Ahlberg

For The Jolly Postman see CRITICS: Johnson; CURRICULUM: Williams.

Louisa May Alcott

Lant, Kathleen Margaret, and Angela M. Estes. "The Feminist Redeemer: Louisa Alcott's Creation of the Female Christ in Work." Christianity and Literature 40.3 (Spring 1991): 223-53. A reading of the novel as a parable which tells "a revolutionary tale about female accomplishment" by the Christlike Christie Devon. G.A.

Laird, Susan. "The Ideal of the Educated Teacher-'Reclaiming a Conversation' with Louisa May Alcott." Curriculum Inquiry 21.3 (Fall 1991): 271-97. A response to Jane Roland Martin's Reclaiming a Conversation: The Ideal of the Educated Woman (Yale UP) in the light of Alcott's philosophy of education as it is revealed in her fiction for children. G.A.

Shealy, Daniel. "Louisa May Alcott's Juvenilia: Blueprints for the Future." Children's Literature Association Quarterly 17.4 (Winter 1992-93): 15-18. Describes the March girls' family publication, The Pickwick Portfolio, and demonstrates how Alcott drew upon juvenilia for her mature work. G.A.

Stern, Madeleine B. "The No Name Series." With a bibliography by Daniel Shealy. Studies in the American Renaissance 1991: 375-402. An account of Roberts Brothers' anonymous series published between 1876 and 1887. Deals with Alcott, Helen Hunt Jackson, and Jean Ingelow. E.K.

For Eight Cousins, see CRITICS: Phillips.

Lloyd Alexander

May, Jill. Lloyd Alexander. Twayne's United States Authors Series. Boston: G.K. Hall, 1991. Pp. xv + 164. ISBN 0-8057-7622-2. The first comprehensive study of Alexander to date deals almost exclusively with his works for children. Based in part on interviews; a clearly written and sympathetic study. G.A.

Tunnell, Michael O. The Prydain Companion: A Reference Guide to Lloyd Alexander's Prydain Chronicles. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1989. Review Norma Bagnall, Children's Literature Association Quarterly 16.2 (Summer 1991): 93-95. Systematic Classification of places, events, and characters; covers spin-offs from the 5-volume series; includes pronunciation guide, appendix, and brief autobiographical sketch. G.A.

Horatio Alger

Kanar, Harvey. "Horatio Alger and Frank's Campaign: White Supremacy in a Northern Intellectual's Juvenile Novel." Children's Literature Association Quarterly 17.1 (Spring 1992): 36-40. Alger's first juvenile novel illustrates the contradictions of Northern abolitionist thought, which separated the institutions of slavery from the concept of racism. G.A.

Nackenoff, Carol. "Of Factories and Failures: Exploring the Invisible Factory Gates of Horatio Alger, Jr." Journal of Popular Culture 25.4 (Spring 1992): 63-80. Describes many of Alger's works for juveniles and argues that the factory as work place is considered to be wholly inadequate for the hero's economic and personal success. L.V.

Rudolfo Anaya

For Bless Me, Ultima see YOUNG ADULT: Klein.

Rachel Anderson

Arabian Nights

Pinault, David. Story-Telling Techniques in the "Arabian Nights." Studies in Arabic Literature 15. Leiden: Brill. ISBN 90-04-095306. Rev. Anthony Burgess, "The Art of Frivolity," Times Literary Supplement 12 June 1992: 22. The methodology of the narrative and its sources going back to the fabular traditions of the ancients. G.A.

Edward Ardizzone

An extensive collection of Ardizzone (1900-1979) has been acquired by the Special Collections Department of the Northern Illinois University Libraries in Dekalb, Illinois, USA. G.A.

Matthew Arnold

Merchant, Peter. "Arnold's Sea of Faithlessness: Margaret, the Merman, and the Cry of the Children." Children's Literature in Education 22.4 (December 1991): 237-46. A revealing close reading of a poem (printed pp. 233-36) once familiar to children. G.A.

Arthurian

Fries, Maureen, and Jeanie Watson, eds. Approaches to Teaching: The Arthurian Tradition. Pp. 182. New York: Modern Language Association, 1992. Cloth, ISBN 0-87352-701-1, $34; paper, ISBN 0-87352-702-X, $19. Includes an essay by Muriel Whitaker, "Arthur for Children." G.A.
